moves.1. e4:
Hi everyone!

I have a collection of games which seem to proove the fact that 2 pieces are better than one rook, even though the side that has the rook may also have a pawn or two for these pieces.  This is Example No.1.  I kick off with 1.e4.
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 Nf6: 2. ...... Nf6 - this is the Petrov's Defense, a counter-attack against the e4 pawn.
moves.3. Nxe5 Qe7: 3. ...... Qe7 - skewers my knight against my e4 pawn and winning it very soon.
moves.4. d4: 4. d4 - supports e5 knight and opens up a diagonal for Fou Lenoir.
moves.5... Nxe5 6. dxe5 Qxe5: 6. ........ Qxe5 - after a knight trade on e5 black has now restored material equality.
moves.7. f4 Qe6 8. Qd4: 8. Qd4 - Glenda decides to come out to play, ah, she still has to defend something though, the pawn on e4!
moves.11. Bf3: 11. Bf3 - Fou Leblanc decides to lend more support to my e4 pawn.
moves.11... c6 12. Qe3 Ng4 13. Bxg4 Qxg4: 13. ........ Qxg4 - after Glenda decides to go back indoors there follows a B for N trade.  Glenda moves to f3 to try to drive back the Wicked Witch of the West.  The Witch flies back to d7.
moves.14. Qf3 Qd7 15. Bd2: 15. Bd2 - Fou Lenoir finally emerges and the rooks are connected.
moves.15... Qc7 16. Kh1: 16. Kh1 - Henry moves into the corner because he does not want to see the Witch on b3!  He likes her not!
moves.16... Be6 17. b3 Rad8 18. Ne2 d5 19. exd: 19. ........ Bxd5 - after a little bit of piece moving there is a pawn trade.
moves.20. Qe3 Rfe8 21. Bc3: 21. Bc3 - Fou Lenoir controls the long diagonal, I consider moving Glenda to g3 next move.
moves.21... Bf6 22. Qf2: 22. Qf2 - Glenda had to sidestep a discovery but now a combo from my opponent leads to the 2 piece for rook imbalance - hence the title of this annotation.
moves.22... Rxe2 23. Qxe2 Bxc3 24. Rad1: 24. Rad1 - my queen rook centralises but that bishop pair do look ominous.
moves.24... Bf6 25. Rd3 b5 26. Qd2 a6 27. c3: 27. c3 - trying to shut off part of the enemy dsb's long diagonal.
moves.27... a5 28. Rd1 Re8 29. Re3 Rxe3 30. Qx: 30. Qxe3 - rook trade, but those 2 enemy bishops still look ominous.
moves.33... Kh7 34. Re3: 34. Re3 - must defend the c3 pawn.
moves.38. Rd3 Kxf4 39. g3+: 39. g3+ - after I lose a pawn, another spite check.
moves.39... Ke4 40. Rd1 Bd4+ 41. Kf1 Ke5: 41. ....... Ke5 - white is very tied up now.
moves.42. Rc1 f5 43. Re1+ Be4 44. Ke2: 44. Ke2 - I am very close to being in a zugzwang.
moves.49. Ke2 f3+ 50. Kd1 f2: 50. ...... f2 - black is very close to getting a queen.  Henry moves to e2 to stop it.
moves.51. Ke2 Bd4 52. Kf1: 52. Kf1 - the only move to avoid immediate loss but Bd3+ forces Henry to g2 and the pawn will crown forcing me to give up my rook.  I therefore resign on the grounds of ruinous loss of material.  Hope you've enjoyed this, part 2 will be coming up very shortly.

gameName: Material Imbalances - 2 pieces are better than 1 rook Pt.1
